title: 110_s2769
content:
The "Firearms Information Use Act of 2008" defines "covered firearms information" as data in the Firearms Trace System database, information required by licensees under section 923(g) of title 18, and data needed to be reported under specific sections of title 18. It also clarifies terms like "firearm," "licensee," and "qualified civil liability action." The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2008 is amended to remove certain provisions related to funding for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. Additionally, amendments are made to the Science, State, Justice, Commerce, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2006 regarding data immunity and legal processes. Amendments are made to provisions related to funding for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives in fiscal years 2003, 2004, and 2005. The amendments take effect immediately and apply to pending requests for information. The amendments apply to evidence admissibility in proceedings before or after the enactment date, regardless of any appropriations Act provision. SEC. 4. LIMITATIONS ON DISCLOSURE AND USE IN CIVIL PROCEEDINGS. (a) Upon request from law enforcement, government agencies, or officials, the Attorney General must provide covered firearms information for law enforcement, national security, or intelligence purposes.
(b) No disclosure of covered firearms information that could compromise undercover officers, ongoing investigations, or the identity of lawful firearm purchasers is allowed.
(c) Covered firearms information can be used in civil proceedings with limitations. Information from the Firearms Trace System database maintained by the National Trace Center of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives cannot be used in qualified civil liability actions, except for in-camera review to determine if it qualifies as such. It also cannot be used if it identifies undercover law enforcement officers or confidential informants. This restriction does not apply to governmental administrative proceedings. The disclosed firearms information cannot be used in certain legal actions initiated by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives or government agencies related to licenses.
